title-group.article-title: Reverse Splits and Shareholder Wealth: The Impact of Commissions

abstract.p: In a recent "Financial Management" article, Woolridge and Chambers presented empirical evidence of statistically significant negative share returns following both the announcement of a reverse share split proposal and the effective day of the reverse split. These results suggest the possibility that investors can use this information to obtain excess returns. This note examines the influence of transactions costs on the findings of the Woolridge and Chambers study. We have found evidence that investors who already own the shares can earn significant positive returns by selling their shares at the closing price on the day the reverse split becomes effective and repurchasing them 5 days later. On the other hand, short sales appear to offer very limited possibilities for positive returns to those investors not already owning the stock. Moreover, there is no evidence of profitable trading strategies, even for those already owning the shares, around the date at which a proposal for a reverse split is first announced.
